headline.main: Fixing Holes in the Health Care Net (7 Letters)
headline.print_headline: Fixing Holes in the Health Care Net

docs.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (AP) — The insurance company Cigna Corporation reported a 19 percent decline in first-quarter profit Wednesday and issued an forecast for the full year that fell short of Wall Street's estimates.
docs.snippet: PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (AP) — The insurance company Cigna Corporation reported a 19 percent decline in first-quarter profit Wednesday and issued an forecast for the full year that fell short of Wall Street's estimates.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Shen Family Foundation is giving $1 million to a 150-seat theater in Arlington, Va., to be spent on the creation of new musicals.

headline.main: Former Investment Banker Becomes a Songwriters' Angel
headline.print_headline: Putting His Wallet Where His Heart Is

docs.snippet: The Shen Family Foundation is giving $1 million to a 150-seat theater in Arlington, Va., to be spent on the creation of new musicals.

docs.lead_paragraph: It was 7:30 on a recent weekday, and a dozen small-business owners, coffee and muffins in hand, were already hard at work on how they were going to win Congressional relief for their No. 1 problem: rising health care costs. From across Virginia, people like Mary L. DeViney of Tuel Jewelers, who had driven two and a half hours from Charlottesville, gathered to discuss their priorities with Todd A. Stottlemyer, the new president of the National Federation of Independent Business.

headline.main: Amassing the Troops For Political Battle

docs.abstract: Ameristar Casinos ends acquisition bid for Aztar Corp; company had offered $1.71 billion for Phoenix-based operator of Tropicana casinos; Pinnacle Entertainment topped Ameristar's offer on April 28 with $1.85 billion bid (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: When will Republicans, Democrats and other special-interest groups realize that American businesses are in business to provide goods and services and make a profit? They are not in business to be health care providers for their employees.

headline.main: Fixing Holes in the Health Care Net

docs.abstract: Fredrick W Cotton letter says American businesses are in business to provide goods and services and make profit, not to be health care providers for their employees (May 1 Paul Krugman Op-Ed column)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     When will Republicans, Democrats and other special-interest groups realize that American businesses are in business to provide goods and services and make a profit? They are not in business to be health care providers for their...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I am one of those 46 million folks without health insurance. The desperately poor receive health care through Medicaid, and illegal immigrants are given free health care, too. This is as it should be.

headline.main: Fixing Holes in the Health Care Net

docs.abstract: Letter from Susan Wexler, who has no health insurance, calls for expansion of Medicare program to cover all uninsured Americans (May 1 Paul Krugman Op-Ed column)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     I am one of those 46 million folks without health insurance. The desperately poor receive health care through Medicaid, and illegal immigrants are given free health care, too. This is as it should be.

headline.main: Fixing Holes in the Health Care Net

docs.abstract: Letter from Prof Caroline Acker praises Paul Krugman's suggestion to expand Medicare to cover entire population (May 1 Op-Ed column); drawing
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Death by Insurance,'' by Paul Krugman (column, May 1):

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Paul Krugman suggests that if Medicare were extended to cover everyone, it ''would save money, reduce financial anxiety and save thousands of American lives every year.'' He asks, ''Why don't we just do it?''

headline.main: Fixing Holes in the Health Care Net

docs.abstract: Letter from United Health Services president Peter McGinn says America will not provide Medicare for everyone until underlying free-market economic model is successfully challenged (May 1 Paul Krugman Op-Ed column)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Paul Krugman suggests that if Medicare were extended to cover everyone, it ''would save money, reduce financial anxiety and save thousands of American lives every year.'' He asks, ''Why don't we just do it?''

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Paul Krugman, in his fine pitch for a single-payer health care system, asks, ''Why don't we just do it?'' The answer, of course, is hidden in his statement that 20 cents of every health insurance dollar goes into ''profits, marketing and administrative expenses,'' in which the second item includes the many millions of dollars paid by the health care industries to lobby Congress.

headline.main: Fixing Holes in the Health Care Net

docs.abstract: Owen C Thomas letter says reason America does not institute single-payer health care system is that it would eliminate lobbying by health care industry (May 1 Paul Krugman Op-Ed column)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Paul Krugman's suggestion that the Medicare system be transformed into a national single-payer system should begin with the announcement of that as a goal.

headline.main: Fixing Holes in the Health Care Net

docs.abstract: John Kapel letter says Paul Krugman's suggestion that Medicare be transformed into national single-payer system should be phased in over time (May 1 Op-Ed article)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Paul Krugman's suggestion that the Medicare system be transformed into a national single-payer system should begin with the announcement of that as a goal.
